name: Tin(IV) chloride
desc: Tin(IV) chloride, also known as tin tetrachloride or stannic chloride, is a inorganic compound with the formula SnCl4. At room temperature it is a colourless liquid, which fumes on contact with air, giving a stinging odor. It is used as a precursor to other tin compounds. It was first discovered by Andreas Libavius (1550–1616) and was known as spiritus fumans libavii.
Appearance: colorless to slightly yellow fuming liquid
Solubility: soluble in alcohol, benzene, toluene, chloroform, acetone, kerosene, CCl4, methanol, gasoline, CS2
Other anions:
Tin(IV) fluoride
Tin(IV) bromide
Tin(IV) iodide
Other cations:
Carbon tetrachloride
Silicon tetrachloride
Germanium tetrachloride
Tin(II) chloride
Lead(IV) chloride
